title: Bringing dark pools to Hyperliquid with Silhouette Founder Chandler De Kock

rawLines.text: Hello and welcome to the Cryptobe. My
name is Tim Copeland from the Box head
of growth. Joining me today, we have
Chandler Dork, founder of Silhouette.
Welcome to the show. How's it going?
Good, good. Thanks for having me.
Brilliant. Before we get started, just a
quick note. If you are hiring in crypto,
you should use Campus, the block's
hiring platform. Help you pick out the
real crypto natives. Head to the
block.co/campus
to get a three-month free trial. Now
today's episode is about dark pores on
hyperlquid a fairly new development
something that silhouette is hoping to
bring out. So can you sort of explain
what is silhouette and what are dark
pools? Oh, dark pools is a concept that
comes from traditional finance.
Typically, how you know trading happens
in the uh traditional finance world is
you've got your stock exchanges, the New
York Stock Exchange, the London Stock
Exchange, and these are really good
anchoring points for price discovery and
for the market to coordinate around. Now
they use different mechanisms um in
different types of markets and but most
of the time they they look like central
order limit books um much to what you
can see in like you know on Coinbase and
Kraken um now today hyperlquid
um and these types of trading mechanisms
are really really good for you to enter
and exit markets for most of the use
cases. Um, one of the other interesting
developments that happened when you kind
of coordinate your trading on these
mechanisms is that if everyone were to
kind of do their trades on these
mechanisms, you would end up kind of
slipping the market if you were to trade
in size or you wanted to trade kind of
OTC or do a different use a different
mechanisms. Um, one way particularly
that you would do it offbook. Um, this
is where kind of these dark pools uh
emerged in finance. Now darkpools in
finance is just simply kind of one firm
trading with another firm and that trade
would not necessarily be disclosed in
any way shape or form. So the details of
the trade would not necessarily be open
and transparent and this gave kind of
just like another venue for for traders
to trade. And one of the key features
there was um the privacy that it
enabled. This is really an important
development because in markets where
price discovery and typically in
traditional market price discovery was
quite easy to find because you know the
reporting standards made price discovery
a concept that was fairly simple
um to for for most traders to get access
to. These dark pools actually enhance
the ability for more traders to trade.
And so what we noticed is that you know
in with the addition of privacy being
added to these traditional markets we
basically had more trade happen as a net
result. Now the transparency that we see
in DeFi basically just gets a lot of
that reporting and kind of just like
access to the information around price
discovery open to everyone to use. you
basically just need an RPC provider and
you can read the state from any sort of
chain kind of at a very very cheap at
very very low costs. Um and so what
we're looking at wanting to build is a
different mechanism to enable some of
these private trading components not
necessarily quite like in the definition
of a darkpool in the traditional world
but bring some of those components into
the DeFi space. And kind of a key
component here on why we think this is
super important is most of the
traditional kind of institutions that
are looking at coming on chain somewhat
desire and demand some of these

features.
 Sure thing. So how does
silhouette work? How does it keep

transactions private?
 At the basis of
what we're building on the techack side
is some of the more um traditional types
of cryptography that get enabled in the
world. trusted execution environments um
have been around for ages. Uh these are
you know your your
uh fingerprint scanner on your MacBook
Pro that uses a a secure enclave to kind
of keep data protected within a a larger
computer. So you can kind of think of it
as this like protected computer within a
larger computer. Um in addition to that
like so that's where we can kind of run
a lot of these like matching components
to provide the the privacy that we need.
But then there is this other component
that really kind of a lot of the ZK side
of the world FHE and MPC type technology
stacks really come into play. Uh so we
can generate a proof from this trusted
uh execution environment to tie into
like the onchain settlement. So from
like a a buildout perspective,
Silhouettes, you know, three components.
Traders submit their order. That's the
one component to Silhouette. We use
these secure enclaves to privately match
trades and order flow. And then the last
component is settlement where we use ZK
to ultimately settle onchain. And in
this in our specific case for our first
kind of like roll out of our product
that'll kind of go into um the

hyperlquid ecosystem.
 Okay. So when you
say so you use the trust execution
environments where is that where the
trades actually take place? So it's sort
of done off
uh offline or at least on your sort of

the company's hardware.
 Yeah. So you can
kind of think of a a trading environment
as this like execution engine where it
basically kind of matches orders uh
according to certain logic. So one logic
can be the way that unis swap does it.
So unis swap uses the uh the the um in
unis swap v3 they've got these limit
order type concepts. Unis swap v2 had
the curve. Uh, Hyperlquid has a central
order limit book. So, whatever that
logic is, you can run that on basically
any piece of hardware. Um, and you can
run it on a server. That's just like a
centralized version of how this would

bit more security guarantees around what
the actual matching engine is doing.

Okay. So, so is it decentralized
 in the
world of decentralization? What does
decentralization mean? It's like how
many people can run the node that
ultimately gets consensus.
Now in Ethereum I can spin up my node at
home. I need 32 ETH can kind of get that
set up fairly fairly simply and now I'm
part of this decentralized network. In
some other chains there's far less nodes
um and that kind of you could assume
it's less decentralized. There's like
Nakamoto coefficient um is a good
example of how decentralized a network

would kind of introduce decentralization
is by having multiple of these execution
environments running together. So if one
went down the network as a whole would
not necessarily break down. So um
decentralization also is quite an
important path that many teams kind of
overindex on in the beginning that leads
to some sort of stifling in the future.
So we have a path to decentralization.
um that path will be kind of taken a
little bit more cautiously from our
perspective. So we'll have like a small
subnet of these trusted execution
environments running in the beginning.
We'll figure out that you know is this
product something that we know where
does this product fit within the market
and you know what are the key features
that we would want to enable that users
would use and once that kind of starts

a little bit easier for us to
rationalize around. So um you know we're
we're starting very centralized in the
beginning with a few execution
environments and then slowly like
increasing that over time when the value
is kind of makes sense for
these networks to actually become

decentralized.
 Let's say if you have
other people setting up these trusted
execution environments, how do you know
that what they're doing is according to
the specific rules that you want to be
in place? And then also how do people
know that your environment is subject to

those rules?
 So we achieve this by kind
of like working through a couple there's
a couple layers to this. The first layer
that kind of makes what the guarantees
of what you're running within these
execution environments is that even if
I'm the I'm running the software. So
Tim, you running one of our trusted
execution environments, you can't access
what's happening on the inside of that
enclave. So even if you own the hardware
and run the hardware um and then kind of
like want to tamper with the system, we
you can't do that. So these these are
why these enclaves are super secure and
the the access to them is very very
tightly controlled. The only thing that

we're kind of working with um some of
these TE providers to kind of add some

like you know the code that runs inside

within the enclave you can generate an

what the code is going to do. It did
what it did and then you can generate a

the settlement proofs um that go onchain

sure that like you know access to these

gated, we can also make sure that the

to show the user, oh at the end of the
day what you said it should do, it
actually did and here's the verification

of that.
 Okay. So if someone else sets
up uh one of these environments, they
don't build it themselves. You would
give them the secure enclave. Is that

 Yeah. So uh there are a couple

Now in the future let's say anyone wants

So why did you choose Hyperlquid as a
base for this platform? Like why did you

choose to build on it?
 Every time a new
cryptographic paradigm came out prior to
you know what we have today the first
thing developers developed was a
darkpool. you know, ZK, they built ZK
dark pools. they built an FG dark
pool. NPC, you name it. There's there's
hundreds of these implementations of how
you can build privacy trading
mechanisms. And by and large, most of
them have failed for a couple reasons.
One of them is that they typically like
have low liquidity. And you know,
liquidity normally kind of has alpha
attached to it. And the privacy is there
to protect the alpha. And so there's no
liquidity, there's no alpha. And so
traders typically haven't really just
like bootstrapped these markets um
relatively efficiently because privacy
in itself doesn't sell. Privacy sells
only in the pursuit of protecting alpha.
And so when we were looking at how we
could implement our version of this, it
was really more a goto market question
as opposed to a technical question. And
when you looked at how liquidity
typically flowed, Hyperliquid was kind
of growing as this nexus point for a

a couple traders, but not really as on
the map as it is today. And so they grew
a community quite organically. They they
also developed um pretty much the the
standard of how Dexes will be deployed
going forward. And when we looked at
kind of a venue for where we could tie
these dark pools into, it was very clear
to us that we needed to tie into a
really sufficiently um kind of robust
ecosystem. And that's where Hyperlid
came in. And so for us the the choice
was more a case of we we knew that just
privacy but for privacy's sake was not
going to be enough of a sufficient set
of tools uh for traders to come
organically to an isolated market. But
instead bringing privacy to where a lot
of alpha is already being generated by a
lot of these traders that are trading
organically. And so therefore, like it
made sense to build alongside a liquid
venue as opposed to just simply an

isolated privacy deck.
 And how bullish

ecosystem?
 I think their track record

we're seeing a bunch of projects come

there. And so for most of the users, one
of the areas that they will be able or
one of these app developers um will tie
into
who would want to leverage against
whatever the assets they have can tie
into a lending market that then has the
backs stop of an entirely like you know
extremely well functioning L1 DEX. So
the bootstrapping problem for this for
the chain is kind of already solved and
these liquidity engines is what saves
chains. Look at Unis swap for Ethereum.
look at GMX for arbitum. That's kind of
what generates most of the activity for
these chains and almost all of DeFi
requires these liquidity engines.
And then the secondary part that I think
is like kind of more exciting that's a
little bit more future-looking um is uh
concepts like HIPP3 where you can deploy
your own per markets that basically with
just a subset of requirements
um can I think you need to stake a
million hype um as a security mechanism
you can generate and create your own
purpose markets kind of really kind of
owning the decentralization component of
of you know create your own markets Now
the third part um that I'm quite excited
about as to like why this is going to be
quite interesting is if you think about
how
um most teams list their coins now they
typically go to their uh to a Binance
they sell their souls to the devil that
deals never in favor of the project and
it's almost extractive but you can't not
have your token not launched on Binance
because that component in itself um is
what gets gets a lot of people

token strategy this is an extremely

any other ecosystem out there.
 And then
what were your thoughts on James Win

really good amount of attention after
that and it really highlights the case
of what some of the the problems are for

chain. So when when you know James kind

Um but if you're a larger institution or

And is it rewarding to see CZ saying

 Yeah, I think

 I didn't

Any anything funny that came out of

Well, I guess I I think the salient

Or does the transaction information

 You know,
blockchains will always be blockchains
and that information will always be
public. So, I don't think the concept of
what was in Andrew Tate's wallet or in
James Win's wallet is necessarily going
to change. It's it's completely new
ecosystem. But in terms of you know if
if you think about what traders care

when trades are live and when they're in

to the trader and that's what they would

the concept of having traders personal

the unique differentiator where most of

do believe that DeFi offers this, you

is somewhat of a nuance kind of

 And what are the biggest

the the technology. So about 2 three

a at a pace that today we've got like

the text matured to a point where it

the next kind of component is really
understanding what do traders actually

of tools like what we would provide
actually care about? I think there's
there's you know the the case is kind of
obvious but when you ask them you know
what do you care about when when you
want to protect your privacy? what
levels of latency do you care about? You
know, there's a lot of minutiae around
that that I think um is somewhat like
unexplored in the public sphere. Most
folks that kind of work in the privacy
space either care about full privacy and
most folks in the market space don't
really know too much about the

overlap of teams like ourselves and a
couple others that care about that
intersection and kind of building a
product that really caters for that
intersection for us is is is what we've
kind of been spending the last 6 months
deeply deeply understanding and it takes
a lot of conversations. It takes a lot
of research and it takes a lot of
security reviews to kind of make sure
the system that you build out at the end
of the day matches both user demand and
ultimately the security requirements for
working on chain today. Yeah. And how do
dark pools work with uh market makers?
Like is it possible for market makers to
participate in them or does it not

really work?
 Yeah, of course. So each
dark pool's constructed somewhat
differently. I think there's there's
very many ways that you could go about
it. So it depends on how you would
implement it. If you've got um a central
order limit book running inside one of
these enclaves, then yes, of course, you
can have market makers participate. Um,
some darkpool mechanisms use RFQ or a
request for quote. So, it's just a
simple quote. You just know the the the
details of what that quote would be and
a market maker can just simply say yes
or no to that. Um, and so it's very
mechanism dependent. Um, but most market
makers are actually dark pools in
themselves. Their OTC desks work in a
very similar concept for the same
somewhat economic need. So market makers
for a long time have been the crypto
equivalent of darkpools. Um there just
hasn't been sort of like a a marketplace
coordination mechanism or product out
there to allow multiple market makers
and multiple users to start kind of
aggregating some of these deal flows.
And what are your next steps for going

live?
 The team's been doing our internal
testing over the past couple weeks. Um
we will be going through a process of
you know kicking the tires, polishing
some of the the components. Um getting
some some very very critical user
feedback on what we can improve. Uh soon
after that the goal would naturally be
to kind of extend that into a broader
beta testing phase. um that beta testing
phase will be um where we kind of go
live within the hyperlquid ecosystem on
mainet and then uh post that it's just
feature enhancements, performance
improvements and naturally kind of you
know catering to to the types of trades
traders would want to place using
mechanisms.
And when are you targeting a launch
date? launch dates TVD um it's
interesting from a from a a web 3
perspective it typically works in these
waterfall mechanisms where you develop a
whole bunch of code you somewhat have
the the product at like near complete
state you ship it off to an auditor they
review it and then you kind of publish
your contracts you you you stitch
everything together and you launch it
that process typically takes quite a lot
of time um mainly just because the
contracts needed be in somewhat of a
finalized state. And so the the approach
that most teams take um in web 2 is
typically been very iterative. Make the
basic system work end to end and then
bolt-on features afterwards. Um for web
3, it's somewhat a different process. So
we're kind of in the final stages of
finalizing our our contracts, getting
them securely reviewed and then you know
once that process completes security can
be anywhere from you know two to 3 weeks
to somewhere to two to three months and
it all depends on the complexity of the
system and and ultimately the the the
feature set that you want to launch

with.
 And are you going to do like a
points program or something? It's
interesting that the points matter has
become so valuable in the space um as an
initial kind of user attraction. I think
there is a case that you know we're
definitely considering points and we're
definitely considering incentive
mechanisms in general. Um, one of the
the natural benefits of of kind of
building these these off-chain privacy
matching engines is that you're not
beholden to the same fee structure from
as a typical exchange. And so, you know,
we we might be considering like straight
up revenue streams as part of the the
benefit that we have. So, you know,
you're trading on Silhouette, you could
get fee rebates, you could kind of, you
know, any savings that you have as a
function of your execution, that could
be a benefit. Um, and then also the
points program. So, you know, balancing
how do we actually ultimately build out
a compelling reason for users to use us
over and above just privacy is is
something that we've been deeply
discussing with some folks. TBD on a
points program. Um, I find them very
interesting as as bootstrapping
mechanisms and for us we just kind of
want to be thoughtful on their

application.
 Do you think you'll do a

token?
 Same same thought pattern as
points
and also same thought pattern under the
decentralization component. What's the
token for is quite a deep question that
many teams I think didn't early early on
was you know a very easy oh we're
decentralized the protocols governed by
this token and then they had the
headache of managing the governance
token when trying to implement new
features and grow and kind of like
develop their ecosystem. I think this is
a little bit of an inhibitor um at this
point in time. I also think folks are
kind of tired of these altcoin tokens
launching having, you know, very
fractional adoption, very fractional
like amount of time that they remain
relevant. Um, and so realistically, like
is this the right market to launch a

right now. And so when we're considering
token a token launch from our
perspective, we we again think through
the incentives, think through why why
why the token really matters, but also
added to the fact that tokens are
normally a decentralization force. So
distributing your token to the
community, what's the value of holding
the token, I think Hyperlid have done a

something that we'll probably also even

and after there's initial user traction.
What's your vision if Silhouette

succeeds?
 The clear metric that I kind

the value proposition for for that for

pushes the the frontier of DeFi a lot

an attraction for net new capital into

They'll naturally go through the

cleanText:
Hello and welcome to the Cryptobe. My name is Tim Copeland from The Block, Head of Growth. Joining me today, we have Chandler De Kock, founder of Silhouette. Welcome to the show. How's it going? Good, good. Thanks for having me. Brilliant. Before we get started, just a quick note. If you are hiring in crypto, you should use Campus, The Block's hiring platform. Help you pick out the real crypto natives. Head to theblock.co/campus to get a three-month free trial. Now today's episode is about dark pools on Hyperliquid, a fairly new development, something that Silhouette is hoping to bring out. So can you sort of explain what is Silhouette and what are dark pools? Oh, dark pools is a concept that comes from traditional finance. Typically, how you know trading happens in the uh traditional finance world is you've got your stock exchanges, the New York Stock Exchange, the London Stock Exchange, and these are really good anchoring points for price discovery and for the market to coordinate around. Now they use different mechanisms um in different types of markets and but most of the time they they look like central order limit books um much to what you can see in like you know on Coinbase and Kraken um now today Hyperliquid um and these types of trading mechanisms are really really good for you to enter and exit markets for most of the use cases. Um, one of the other interesting developments that happened when you kind of coordinate your trading on these mechanisms is that if everyone were to kind of do their trades on these mechanisms, you would end up kind of slipping the market if you were to trade in size or you wanted to trade kind of OTC or do a different use a different mechanism. Um, one way particularly that you would do it off-book. Um, this is where kind of these dark pools uh emerged in finance. Now dark pools in finance is just simply kind of one firm trading with another firm and that trade would not necessarily be disclosed in any way shape or form.
